articles.headline: In Russia, Pollution Is Good for Business
articles.snippet: By its own admission, Russia's electricity monopoly is the world's largest corporate producer of greenhouse gases, accounting -- by itself -- for nearly as much carbon dioxide as is emitted by Britain.      From smokestacks across Russia's 11 time...
articles.abstract: By its own admission, Russia's electricity monopoly is the world's largest corporate producer of greenhouse gases, accounting -- by itself -- for nearly as much carbon dioxide as is emitted by Britain.      From smokestacks across Russia's 11 time zones, the company, Unified Energy Systems, spews out 2 percent of all human-generated carbon dioxide accumulating in the atmosphere.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 24 - By its own admission, Russia's electricity monopoly is the world's largest corporate producer of greenhouse gases, accounting -- by itself -- for nearly as much carbon dioxide as is emitted by Britain.

articles.headline: Defense Lawyers in Terror Cases Plan Challenges Over Spy Efforts
articles.snippet: Defense lawyers in some of the country's biggest terrorism cases say they plan to bring legal challenges to determine whether the National Security Agency used illegal wiretaps against several dozen Muslim men tied to Al Qaeda.     The lawyers sai...
articles.abstract: Defense lawyers in some of the country's biggest terrorism cases say they plan to bring legal challenges to determine whether the National Security Agency used illegal wiretaps against several dozen Muslim men tied to Al Qaeda.     The lawyers said in interviews that they wanted to learn whether the men were monitored by the agency and, if so, whether the government withheld critical information or misled judges and defense lawyers about how and why the men were singled out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 - Defense lawyers in some of the country's biggest terrorism cases say they plan to bring legal challenges to determine whether the National Security Agency used illegal wiretaps against several dozen Muslim men tied to Al Qaeda.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and James Risen

articles.headline: Plea Deal Is Seen for Enron Figure
articles.snippet: In a reversal that transforms the criminal case against Enron's former top officers, the company's former chief accounting officer has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to violating federal law during his employment there, peop...
articles.abstract: In a reversal that transforms the criminal case against Enron's former top officers, the company's former chief accounting officer has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to violating federal law during his employment there, people briefed on the decision said yesterday.      The former accounting officer, Richard A. Causey, had been viewed by lawyers in the case as likely to strike a plea deal with prosecutors and possibly serve as a witness for the government in the coming trial of two former chief executives of Enron, Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a reversal that transforms the criminal case against Enron's former top officers, the company's former chief accounting officer has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to violating federal law during his employment there, people briefed on the decision said yesterday.

articles.headline: Verizon Loses Some Edge Atop the Bells
articles.snippet: Is the Verizon premium fading?     For the last few years, Verizon's stock has traded more than 30 percent above its Baby Bell peers -- AT&T, BellSouth and Qwest -- because investors felt it had more valuable, wealthier customers in the Northeast,...
articles.abstract: Is the Verizon premium fading?     For the last few years, Verizon's stock has traded more than 30 percent above its Baby Bell peers -- AT&T, BellSouth and Qwest -- because investors felt it had more valuable, wealthier customers in the Northeast, and because its cellular group, Verizon Wireless, was the industry's most profitable.

articles.headline: Limbo, an Afterlife Tradition, May Be Doomed by the Vatican
articles.snippet: It may seem half a shame to get rid of a church tradition, however cruel and antiquated, if it can inspire poetry like ''The Inferno'' or spooky lines like these from Seamus Heaney: ''Fishermen at Ballyshannon/Netted an infant last night/Along wit...
articles.abstract: It may seem half a shame to get rid of a church tradition, however cruel and antiquated, if it can inspire poetry like ''The Inferno'' or spooky lines like these from Seamus Heaney: ''Fishermen at Ballyshannon/Netted an infant last night/Along with the salmon.''      But limbo, that netherworld of unbaptized babies and worthy pagans, is very much on the way out -- another lesson that while belief in God may not change, the things people believe about him most certainly do.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME, Dec. 27 - It may seem half a shame to get rid of a church tradition, however cruel and antiquated, if it can inspire poetry like "The Inferno" or spooky lines like these from Seamus Heaney: "Fishermen at Ballyshannon/Netted an infant last night/Along with the salmon."

articles.headline: Eating Your Way to Health; Companies Are Marketing Fortified Foods to the Drug-Wary
articles.snippet: Ever since she gave birth to her fourth child in 2003, Michelle Celona, a 43-year-old part-time teacher in Philadelphia, had suffered from annoying bouts of constipation. Figuring it was the stress of carting three children around or the result of...
articles.abstract: Ever since she gave birth to her fourth child in 2003, Michelle Celona, a 43-year-old part-time teacher in Philadelphia, had suffered from annoying bouts of constipation. Figuring it was the stress of carting three children around or the result of something that had changed in her body after pregnancy, she learned to live with it.      But when the Dannon Company asked Ms. Celona in June if she wanted to participate in a two-week trial for Activia, a new fortified yogurt that the company said could help speed up what nutritionists delicately refer to as intestinal transit time, she jumped at the chance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since she gave birth to her fourth child in 2003, Michelle Celona, a 43-year-old part-time teacher in Philadelphia, had suffered from annoying bouts of constipation. Figuring it was the stress of carting three children around or the result of something that had changed in her body after pregnancy, she learned to live with it.

articles.headline: Republican Strategist Is Taking Heat for Taking Mexico as Client
articles.snippet: Rob Allyn, the political consultant, meet Rob Allyn, the punching bag.      A longtime Republican strategist, Mr. Allyn has found himself in the cross hairs of conservative critics in the last week after signing a contract with Mexico's foreign mi...
articles.abstract: Rob Allyn, the political consultant, meet Rob Allyn, the punching bag.      A longtime Republican strategist, Mr. Allyn has found himself in the cross hairs of conservative critics in the last week after signing a contract with Mexico's foreign ministry to lead a campaign to strengthen the country's image in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS, Dec. 26 - Rob Allyn, the political consultant, meet Rob Allyn, the punching bag.

articles.headline: When Chinese Sue the State, Cases Are Often Smothered
articles.snippet: The peasants surrounded the clerk in the busy court anteroom, badgering him to let them sue the officials who had seized their land.     No, no, the clerk said, shaking his head and waving his hands, as the peasants recalled it. They were wasting ...
articles.abstract: The peasants surrounded the clerk in the busy court anteroom, badgering him to let them sue the officials who had seized their land.     No, no, the clerk said, shaking his head and waving his hands, as the peasants recalled it. They were wasting his time and theirs. But as they withdrew, their legal papers remained on his desk in plain sight. Maybe, the peasants hoped, that meant the clerk had tacitly accepted their application to sue.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIQIAO, China - The peasants surrounded the clerk in the busy court anteroom, badgering him to let them sue the officials who had seized their land.

articles.headline: Police Forces, Their Ranks Thin, Offer Bonuses, Bounties and More
articles.snippet: Among the depleted ranks of police departments throughout the country, it has come to this: desperate want ads offering signing bonuses to new recruits, and cops paying other cops to find new cops.     It seems nobody wants to be a police officer ...
articles.abstract: Among the depleted ranks of police departments throughout the country, it has come to this: desperate want ads offering signing bonuses to new recruits, and cops paying other cops to find new cops.     It seems nobody wants to be a police officer anymore, officials say. As a result, departments are taking a page from recruiters in sports and the corporate world. Here in King County, the most populous in the Pacific Northwest, the Sheriff's Office is trying a kind of bounty hunting: any deputy who can bring in someone who eventually becomes an officer will get a bonus of 40 hours of extra vacation time, worth up to $1,300.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE, Dec. 26 - Among the depleted ranks of police departments throughout the country, it has come to this: desperate want ads offering signing bonuses to new recruits, and cops paying other cops to find new cops.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Puts Restrictions on Guidant
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday released a warning letter it sent to the Guidant Corporation, restricting the ability of the company to win approval for some new medical products. In the letter, sent a week ago, the agency said Guidant,...
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday released a warning letter it sent to the Guidant Corporation, restricting the ability of the company to win approval for some new medical products. In the letter, sent a week ago, the agency said Guidant, the heart device maker, had not fully responded to its concerns about manufacturing procedures at the company's biggest plant.     The F.D.A. said that in parts of the company's operations, Guidant did not have adequate controls, procedures and methods to validate product improvements it was making. The agency gave Guidant 15 days to respond. Along with suspending some new product approvals, the F.D.A. said it would no longer issue new export permits for devices made at the company's plant in St. Paul.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday released a warning letter it sent to the Guidant Corporation, restricting the ability of the company to win approval for some new medical products. In the letter, sent a week ago, the agency said Guidant, the heart device maker, had not fully responded to its concerns about manufacturing procedures at the company's biggest plant.
